metadata.title: Sources of History
metadata.subject: History
metadata.description: An introduction to medieval Indian history and the various sources used to study it â€” material, written, and oral â€” along with how historians evaluate their authenticity.

options.B: A Marathi chronicle or historical narrative
options.D: A religious hymn sung by Bhakti saints

concepts.title: What is History and Why Study Sources?
concepts.content: History is the systematic study of the past â€” events, people, societies, and changes over time. To understand the medieval period in India (roughly 9th to 18th century), historians depend on sources. Without sources, we cannot verify what actually happened. Four important factors guide historical study: Individuals (who acted), Society (the community involved), Place (where it happened), and Time (when it happened). All sources must be carefully examined for authenticity â€” a source can be forged, biased, or incomplete. A good historian cross-checks multiple sources before drawing conclusions.
examples: Studying a coin helps us know the name of the king, the era, and the economy.
A folk song about Shivaji tells us how people felt about him emotionally.
An inscription on a temple wall records a royal donation â€” but we must check if it was later altered.
keyPoints: History requires evidence â€” we cannot rely on memory or imagination alone.
Four factors: Individuals, Society, Place, and Time must all be considered.
Sources must be verified for authenticity before being accepted as fact.
Different types of sources give different perspectives on the same event.
Medieval India spans roughly from the 9th to the 18th century.
concepts.funFact: Some historical sources were deliberately destroyed by invaders or rulers who wanted to erase the memory of previous kingdoms â€” making the surviving sources even more precious!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 1, Pages 1-2

concepts.title: Material Sources
concepts.content: Material sources are physical objects left behind from the past. They include coins, forts, cave sculptures, copper plates, inscriptions, memorials, and buildings. Coins are particularly valuable â€” they tell us the name and title of rulers, the language used, and economic conditions. Medieval coins had specific denominations: kavadi (smallest), damadi, dhela, pai, and paisa. Forts are another major source â€” Maharashtra has three types: hill forts (Raigad, Sinhagad), sea forts (Sindhudurg, Janjira), and forest forts. Inscriptions carved on stone or metal record royal grants, victories, and religious dedications. Copper plates (tamrapat) preserved legal records of land grants.
examples: A gold coin of Akbar shows his name in Persian and Arabic, telling us about Mughal trade and language.
The fort of Raigad reveals Shivaji's administrative planning â€” it had palace, market, and public spaces.
Ashoka's inscriptions on rocks across India spread his message of non-violence and good governance.
keyPoints: Material sources are physical objects: coins, forts, sculptures, copper plates, inscriptions, buildings.
Coin denominations: kavadi < damadi < dhela < pai < paisa.
Three types of forts in Maharashtra: hill forts, sea forts, forest forts.
Inscriptions on stone and copper plates record royal grants and proclamations.
Cave sculptures (like Ajanta and Ellora) reveal art, religion, and daily life.
concepts.funFact: The fort of Janjira (a sea fort near Murud) was so well-designed that even the mighty Maratha navy and the British could not capture it for centuries!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 1, Pages 2-3

concepts.title: Written Sources
concepts.content: Written sources include manuscripts, chronicles, royal orders, letters, and account books. Chronicles are detailed historical narratives written about kings and their reigns. The Akbarnama (written by Abul Fazl) narrates the reign of Akbar, while the Ain-i-Akbari describes Akbar's administration in detail. Bakhars are Marathi chronicles that record the history of Maratha rulers, especially Shivaji Maharaj. Letters and royal orders (farmans and aadnyapatra) also provide direct insight into the decisions of rulers. Manuscripts preserved in libraries â€” often on palm leaves or paper â€” contain literature, science, religion, and history of the medieval period.
examples: The Akbarnama by Abul Fazl describes Akbar's campaigns, administration, and personality.
The Shivdigvijay Bakhar narrates the life and conquests of Shivaji Maharaj.
Royal farmans (orders) issued by Mughal emperors are preserved and help us understand their governance.
keyPoints: Written sources include manuscripts, chronicles, letters, and royal orders.
Akbarnama: chronicle of Akbar's reign written by Abul Fazl.
Ain-i-Akbari: detailed account of Akbar's administration and court.
Bakhar: Marathi historical narrative about Maratha rulers.
Written sources can be biased â€” they were often written by people loyal to the ruler.
concepts.funFact: The Ain-i-Akbari is so detailed that it even lists the salaries of court musicians, the varieties of mangoes grown in Akbar's gardens, and the exact weight of elephants in his army!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 1, Page 3

concepts.title: Oral Sources
concepts.content: Oral sources are historical information passed down through word of mouth across generations. They include folk songs, ballads (povadas), proverbs, and legends. In Maharashtra, povadas (ballads) were composed and sung by shahirs (bards) to celebrate the bravery of Shivaji Maharaj and other Maratha heroes. Folk songs and proverbs preserve the feelings, values, and social conditions of common people who did not leave behind written records. Oral sources are valuable because they capture the perspective of ordinary people â€” farmers, soldiers, women â€” who are often absent from official written records. However, oral sources can change over time as they are retold, so they must be verified with other sources.
examples: Povadas composed by Agindas and Tulsidas celebrated Shivaji's victories and character.
Proverbs about farming seasons preserved knowledge of agriculture even among illiterate communities.
Legends about Jijabai teaching young Shivaji stories from the Ramayana and Mahabharata reflect her role in shaping his values.
keyPoints: Oral sources include folk songs, ballads (povadas), proverbs, and legends.
Shahirs (bards) composed and performed povadas about Maratha heroes.
Oral sources capture perspectives of common people not found in official records.
Over time, oral sources can become exaggerated or altered â€” they need cross-checking.
They are especially important in societies with low literacy rates.
concepts.funFact: The shahir Agindas composed a famous povada about the Battle of Pratapgad so vividly that historians use it alongside written records to reconstruct the event!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 1, Pages 3-4

concepts.title: How to Evaluate Sources Critically
concepts.content: Not all historical sources are equally reliable. Historians must critically evaluate every source before using it. Key questions to ask: Who created this source? When was it created? What was the purpose? Is the author a direct witness or writing much later? Is there a political or personal bias? Can it be verified by other independent sources? A source written by an enemy of a ruler may exaggerate their faults, while one written by a loyal minister may only praise them. Material sources like coins and inscriptions are generally more reliable as physical evidence. However, even material sources can be faked (forged coins existed in medieval India). Cross-referencing multiple types of sources â€” material, written, and oral â€” gives the most complete picture of the past.
examples: The Akbarnama was written by Abul Fazl, Akbar's close friend â€” so it naturally praises Akbar and should be read with this bias in mind.
A coin found in an archaeological dig with a known ruler's name and date is strong material evidence of that ruler's reign.
A povada about a battle must be compared with eyewitness accounts to separate heroic exaggeration from factual description.
keyPoints: All sources must be evaluated for authenticity, purpose, and bias.
Consider: who wrote it, when, why, and whether they were a direct witness.
Official sources often reflect the ruler's perspective; common people's views come from oral sources.
Cross-referencing multiple sources â€” material, written, oral â€” is essential for accuracy.
Even material sources like coins can be forged and must be verified scientifically.
concepts.funFact: Modern historians use carbon dating, chemical analysis of metals, and handwriting analysis to verify whether ancient manuscripts and coins are genuine or forgeries!
concepts.textbookRef: Maharashtra Board Class 7 History, Chapter 1, Page 4

test.question: Which of the following is NOT a material source of history?
test.explanation: A Bakhar is a Marathi written chronicle, making it a written source. Copper plates, inscriptions, and coins are all physical objects â€” material sources.

test.question: What is the correct order of medieval coin denominations from smallest to largest?
test.explanation: The correct ascending order is: kavadi (smallest), damadi, dhela, pai, paisa (largest). This was the monetary denomination system in medieval Maharashtra.

test.question: The Akbarnama was written by:
test.explanation: The Akbarnama was written by Abul Fazl, one of Akbar's nine gems (Navratnas) and his close confidant. It is a detailed chronicle of Akbar's reign.

test.question: Which type of fort is Sindhudurg?
test.explanation: Sindhudurg is a famous sea fort built by Shivaji Maharaj off the coast of Malvan in the Arabian Sea. It is one of Maharashtra's most important sea forts.

test.question: What are the four important factors that must be considered while studying history?
test.explanation: According to the textbook, the four important factors for historical study are: Individuals (who were involved), Society (the social context), Place (where events occurred), and Time (when they occurred).

test.question: Why must oral sources be verified with other sources?

options.A: Because oral sources are always false
options.B: Because oral sources can change or get exaggerated as they are retold over generations
options.C: Because oral sources are only useful for music history
options.D: Because governments do not allow oral sources in history books

test.explanation: Oral sources like folk songs and ballads can change over time as they are passed down. Storytellers may exaggerate or add details. Therefore, they must be cross-checked with written and material sources.

test.question: What is a 'povada'?

options.A: A type of coin used in the Maratha period
options.B: A copper plate recording land grants
options.C: A Marathi ballad celebrating the bravery of heroes
options.D: A manuscript written on palm leaves

test.explanation: A povada is a Marathi ballad â€” a type of oral source â€” composed and performed by shahirs (bards) to celebrate the bravery and achievements of Maratha heroes like Shivaji Maharaj.

test.question: Which of the following helps historians understand the economy and rulers of a kingdom most directly?
test.explanation: Coins carry the name, title, and image of the ruler, the language of the kingdom, and reflect trade and economic conditions. They are one of the most direct and reliable material sources.

test.question: What is the Ain-i-Akbari?

options.B: A book describing Akbar's administration, court, and empire in detail
options.D: A record of battles fought by Akbar

test.explanation: The Ain-i-Akbari is a detailed account of Akbar's administration, court organization, provinces, and culture, also written by Abul Fazl. It is different from the Akbarnama, which is a narrative chronicle.

test.question: Which method do modern historians use to verify whether a source is genuine?

options.B: Using carbon dating, chemical analysis, and cross-referencing multiple sources
options.C: Counting the number of pages in a manuscript
options.D: Only trusting sources written in Sanskrit

test.explanation: Modern historians use scientific methods like carbon dating (for age), chemical analysis of metals (for coins), handwriting analysis, and most importantly cross-referencing multiple independent sources to verify authenticity.

keyConcepts: Material sources of history: coins, forts, inscriptions, copper plates, cave sculptures, buildings
Written sources: manuscripts, chronicles (Akbarnama, Ain-i-Akbari, Bakhars)
Oral sources: folk songs, povadas (ballads), proverbs
Four factors of historical study: Individuals, Society, Place, Time
Critical evaluation and verification of historical sources
Medieval coin denominations: kavadi, damadi, dhela, pai, paisa
Types of forts: hill forts, sea forts, forest forts
commonMisconceptions: Students often think oral sources are unreliable and should be ignored â€” in fact they are important for understanding common people's perspectives.
Students may confuse Akbarnama (narrative chronicle) with Ain-i-Akbari (administrative account) â€” both were written by Abul Fazl but serve different purposes.
Many think material sources are always 100% reliable â€” but coins can be forged and inscriptions can be altered.
Students may think history is only about kings and wars â€” the four factors remind us it includes all of society.
realWorldExamples: Just like we use photos, videos, and text messages as evidence today, medieval people left behind coins, buildings, and songs as their evidence.
A WhatsApp message is a 'written source'; a selfie in front of a monument is a 'material source'; a story your grandmother tells is an 'oral source'.
Archaeologists excavating medieval sites in Pune or Aurangabad are collecting material sources just as described in this chapter.
